sentences: Emmelie Charlotte-Victoria de Forest (born 28 February 1993) is a Danish singer and songwriter.
section: N/A

sentences: De Forest represented Denmark with the song "Only Teardrops" in the Eurovision Song Contest 2013 in Malmö, Sweden, winning the contest.
section: N/A

sentences: Her debut album Only Teardrops was released on the Universal Music label on 6 May 2013.
section: N/A

sentences: Her sophomore studio album History was released through the Swedish independent label Cosmos Music on 9 February 2018.
section: N/A
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: De Forest was born in Randers, Denmark, to a Danish mother, Marianna Birgitte Gudnitz and Swedish father, Ingvar de Forest (1938–2010).
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Following her parents' divorce when she was young, she grew up with her mother in Mariager, Denmark, and in Stockholm, Sweden.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: She had previously claimed that she was a great granddaughter of British king Edward VII.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Danmarks Radio used the story of her claim to royal ancestry in its promotion of the Dansk Melodi Grand Prix, although the claim has been discredited by researchers.
section: == Personal life ==
== Music career ==

sentences: Music career ==
section: == Music career ==
== Music career == | === Early career ===

sentences: Early career ===
section: == Music career == | === Early career ===

sentences: De Forest began singing at the age of nine and sang with her mother in the Steve Cameron Gospel Choir for several years.
section: == Music career == | === Early career ===

sentences: From the age of 14, she began performing at music festivals and small venues with Scottish folk musician Fraser Neill.
section: == Music career == | === Early career ===

sentences: According to Neill, they made an album together titled Emmelié de Forest and Fraser Neill that sold only 100 copies.
section: == Music career == | === Early career ===

sentences: When de Forest was 18 years old, she ended her collaboration with Neill and moved to Copenhagen to study at the Complete Vocal Institute.
section: == Music career == | === Early career ===
== Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===
== Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: De Forest was one of ten acts that performed in the 2013 Dansk Melodi Grand Prix for a chance to represent Denmark at the Eurovision Song Contest 2013 in Malmö, Sweden.
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: On 26 January 2013, she performed the song "Only Teardrops" (written by Lise Cabble, Julia Fabrin Jakobsen and Thomas Stengaard) and won the national selection.
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: Her debut album, Only Teardrops, was released on 6 May, a week before her performance in the Eurovision contest.
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: The album has twelve tracks, including the original and symphonic versions of "Only Teardrops.
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: "On 14 May, de Forest reached the final of the Eurovision, being one of the ten finalists that qualified from the first semi-final.
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: According to British bookmakers, de Forest beat the odds on favourite to win the contest.
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: De Forest won the 2013 Eurovision final on 18 May with a total of 281 points, 47 points more than second-place finisher Farid Mammadov of Azerbaijan.
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: She performed her Eurovision winning entry at the Junior Eurovision Song Contest 2013 in Kyiv, Ukraine on 30 November.
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===

sentences: In December it was revealed that de Forest had been awarded the European of the Year Award (Danish: Årets Europæer Award) by the Danish European Movement.
section: == Music career == | === 2013: Eurovision Song Contest and Only Teardrops ===
== Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: 2014–present: Label change and History =
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===
== Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: On 7 February 2014, de Forest uploaded a video that spoke about her third single "Rainmaker", explained the meaning of the song, and previewed it.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: It was the official #JoinUs song for the Eurovision Song Contest 2014 and she performed the song live during the final at the B&W Hallerne, in Copenhagen.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: Talking about the song de Forest said, "It is about a tribe joining together to call upon the rainmaker to make their land blossom again.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: But on a more general level the rainmaker can be anything or anyone – it is about coming together and helping each other out".
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: She also talked about enjoying success after winning Eurovision last year, "I've been performing my music around Europe, released my debut album and written a lot of new songs – to be honest, I'm living my dream!".
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: In a Wiwibloggs interview in September 2014, de Forest said she was recording her second studio album, which was originally due to be released in February 2015.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: On 14 July, de Forest announced that "Rainmaker" was certified Gold.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: On 3 August 2014, de Forest announced via Facebook that she would perform the first single of her yet untitled album, "Drunk Tonight" at Amsterdam Pride 2014.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: Via Instagram, de Forest unveiled the cover and snippets of "Drunk Tonight", as well as its music video preview.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: The single was later released on 18 August, while the music video for the song was released on 25 August.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: De Forest, who appears in a bikini in the video, has said in interviews that she wanted it to be "elegant and sexy" at the same time.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: In December 2015, she left her record label Universal Music Group, and later signed with Swedish record company Cosmos Music.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: De Forest later participated in the British national selection for the Eurovision Song Contest 2017 as a songwriter for the song "Never Give Up on You" performed by Lucie Jones.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: The song went on to win the competition, and later placed 15th at the Eurovision Song Contest in Kyiv.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: De Forest went on to release the single "Sanctuary" in November 2017, her first release since her split from Universal.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: Her second studio album History was released on 9 February 2018.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: Under the independent label Day
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===

sentences: In Day Out Records, a division of Cosmos Music, De Forest released the single "Typical Love Song" on 8 October 2021.
section: == Music career == | === 2014–present: Label change and History ===
